plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome and thank you for joining the Deutsche Bank First Quarter 2010 Analyst Conference Call. As a reminder all participants are in listen-only mode and the conference is recorded. . Ladies and gentlemen at this time you will be joined to the conference room of Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt.

Thank you, Maria. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. It's also my pleasure to welcome you to our first quarter earnings conference call. As usual our CFO, Stefan Krause will go through the presentation in the few seconds, which is available on our website. Of course we will take your questions at the end.

If because of time constraints, you cannot ask all your questions you might have, please come back to investor relations and we will follow-up. Last but not least I would like to remind you to have a look at the slides in the back of the presentation that covers forward-looking statements.
So let's get going, Stefan please.

Thank you very much and Guten Tag from Frankfurt to everybody. Let me start on our first page on the highlights page with the summary of our results. Our quarterly pre-tax profit of €2.8 billion is the second best ever. This resulted in a net income of €1.8 billion. Our pre-tax return on equity of 30% is up on a substantially higher capital base versus the first quarter of 2009. Our Tier-1 capital ratio came out at 11.2%, well above our target of 10% and our leverage ratio, as you can see, is flat at 23 times.

If we move on, on the next chart we put what we think was the very strong first quarter in its historic context. Once again Deutsche Bank has demonstrated its basic strong earnings power. We have achieved the second best quarter ever in both revenues and pre-tax profit as you can see from the chart.

On the next page, you saw we recorded strong revenue of 9 billion compared to 7.2 billion in the first quarter of 2009. As you may remember first quarter 2009 revenues included markdowns and impairments of 1.5 billion in CB&S. This compares with only 241 million in markdowns this quarter, which predominantly related to our monoline.
Revenues in the first quarter 2010 also include 148 million from the first consolidation of Sal. Oppenheim, which resides our consolidated from the 29th of January onward.

To move on to page six, provision for our credit losses, as you see, almost half to €262 million versus the first quarter of 2009. Provisions related to IAS 39 reclassified asset were €104 million in the first quarter, which represents less than half of the 218 million we had in the quarter of '09.

I think that this confirms our guidance that obviously the magnitude of IAS 39 reserves booked in 2009 does not represent a trend going forward at that time. And I would like to highlight again that obviously this is a one time may jump and that we might see continuously volatility in this position.

The core loan books so in CIB which means the loan book excluding these IAS 39 assets experienced very low net provisions in this quarter. Main reason for this number was the successful completion of many restructuring with German mid cap, particularly here in manufacturing and automotive.
Loan loss provisions in PCAM continued to develop favorable, see the decreasing delinquency ratio in small corporate mortgages and consumer loan was put in the appendix.

So to give you further outlook obviously despite this encouraging outcome in the first quarter we would be very hesitant at this point extrapolated first quarter into the full year 2010. There are still as you know many market uncertainties as the economy continues to be very fragile the recovery is very fragile and of course we intend to further reduce our IAS 39 assets, but we don't think we should at this time extrapolate our first quarter results to the full year.
We will therefore not yet change the general guidance that we have given you at the Investor Day at the end of 2009.
We move on to page seven, so you can see that our non-interest expenses of 5.9 billion an increase of 1 billion versus the first quarter of '09 which I'll explain obviously in more detail.

Compensation and benefits in the first quarter 2010 were up about 600 million which reflects the higher deferred compensation of approximately €350 million of which 298 million relates to the acceleration of deferred expenses. This relates to our early retirement rules that were applicable to the February 2010 grant.

There was no comparable effects in the first quarter of 2009. €120 million related to the U.K. bonus tax on a portion of the deferred compensation element, which many of our peers as you know have not yet recorded and there will be more to come in terms of U.K. bonus tax in the second and third quarter. With this payment, U.K. tax authorities will be due in August 2010, but we will not clearly quantify the exact amount yet as the legislation is not final.
And last but no least, obviously the improved business performance resulted in higher compensation accrual.

So our compensation ratio overall was 40%, excluding the effect of the U.K. payroll tax, it was 38%. The increase in these expenses also related to the consolidation of course of Sal. Oppenheim as you can see on the chart. Non-compensation expenses versus the first quarter 2009 were impacted by an increase in IT and professional services.

We move on to page eight. Here the cost basis specific first quarter effect and this effect has a much higher magnitude than in previous year. We wanted to provide you this first time disclosure and there will be a one time disclosure, by the way. We just wanted to make sure that you understand this career retirement effect and its – has impacted quite a bit the performance or the numbers showed of our different divisions.

The slide obviously, gives you more details on this career retirement effect and especially shows that by our separate division. As you can see 230 million were allocated to CB&S, 69 million were allocated to our classic banking business, which were impacted more severely in relative terms.

Furthermore you will notice in this quarter we have already digested nearly 40% of the 2010 portion of the deferred compensation expense for the award made in February of 2010. You can also see that the end of 2010 will already have absorbed almost 60% of the deferred grants awarded in February 2010.

We have included in this chart just to show you the timing and the allocation of this increased deferred compensation expenses and obviously I want to say that we will not foresee to repeat such disclosure in every quarter going forward because it is a specific Q1 event.

We move on to page nine. We saw that in the first quarter 2010 our income before incomes taxes is €2.8 billion, an increase of 54% versus the first quarter of 2009. We generated a return on equity of 30% as I already said on an active equity base which is roughly €4.5 billion higher than the one in the year before.

If we go to page 10, we saw our net income in the first quarter which was €1.8 billion, 50% higher than one year before. Our Effective Tax Rate in the quarter was 36.4%. This first quarter ETR mainly reflects the following items, with a significant change in the regional mix of our result and we obviously have the U.K. bank payroll tax which is not tax deductible. As a result of these two effects, we expect the full year ETR to come in slightly above 35% at this point in time.

On page 11, we discuss our Tier 1 capital ratios. Our Tier 1 capital ratios came in at 11.2 as of March 31. The decrease compared to year end 2009 is mainly driven by the acquisition of Sal. Oppenheim, which had an impact of negative 117 basis points. Please bear in mind as we disclosed that we decided not to raise capital for this acquisition due to our strong capital generation at year end.

Moreover a change in the regulatory reporting of certain securitization provisions in our trading book led to an additional Tier 1 capital deduction of 1.4 billion and we had an – a corresponding deduction in Tier 2 capital, translating into a decrease of 49 basis points in our Tier 1 ratio.

These effects were partially obviously offset by the net income generated in the first quarter which gave us a positive 61 basis points. Our core Tier-1 ratio, which excludes hybrids was the 7.5% at the quarter end.

Our risk weighted asset increased by €23 billion to €292 billion, was also mainly driven by the Sal. Oppenheim acquisition which represented €17 billion and obviously significant movements in the FX effect in the risk weighted asset.

We've provides further details on the development of our Tier-1 capital and risk weighted assets on page 45 of the appendix for your information. In the second quarter, the Tier-1 ratio will be impacted by the acquisition of the ABN AMRO business. We give you this heads up already that we reduce the Tier-1 by 30 to 40 basis points approximately including the expected positive impact from the negative goodwill.
Just to say an additional point, the change in our reporting of our trading book securitization, will reduce the impact of future trading book rules on our book versus our previous estimates.

We move on to page 12, we move on to the balance sheet. Total IFRS assets increased by 169 billion about 11%, mostly driven by higher settlement balances, the strengthening of U.S. dollar, and as I said already the consolidation of Sal. Oppenheim. The U.S. dollar impact on Sal. Oppenheim were also that two main reasons for the 87 billion or 10% increase in our U.S. GAAP Pro Forma asset, which is our balance sheet after netting. The consolidation of Sal. Oppenheim contributed of approximately 30 billion and the strengthening of the U.S. dollar about 28 billion, if you know we make this U.S. GAAP Pro-Forma asset calculation to calculate a comparable leverage ratio with our U.S. peers. The leverage ratio therefore remains unchanged at 23 times, as higher assets are partly compensated by higher equity and increased pro-forma fair value gains on our own debt.

As we move on now to the segment results. On page 14, this slide gives you an overview of the segmental performance during the quarter many of the divisions include some of the negative items which I already talked about and some additional negative items that I'll talk to, as I go through them individually.

Let me only highlight here that the consolidation adjustments reflect the negative trend in revenues of almost 400 million versus previous year quarter. As you may remember in the first quarter of 2009, we benefited from positive timing differences between our segment reporting and our IFRS group reporting due to the situation we had on the interest rate development in the last quarter of 2008. There was a swing back in 2009 that's part of the strong explanation.

And obviously this C&A gets always impacted by timing differences between our segment reporting and our IFRS group reporting overall. This difference is due to a different treatment of an underlying position and its economic edge.

In the first quarter 2009, the bulk of the positive revenues were due to a significant decrease in euro interest rates again these strings do not show real losses or gains, but only reflect timing differences between our segment reports.

On page 15, we show CB&S. we've achieved the best pre-tax profit ever despite the fact that we have some mark-downs of approximately €250 million and the aforementioned increase amortization expense for deferred compensation so we must say we were extremely happy with this result. Obviously the reduced provision for credit losses also contributes to this really outstanding result and pre-tax, return on equity is at the remarkable 69%, which was apart from the record profit situation also benefited from a significant risk reduction. We also could show in this business and therefore lower allocated capital.

On page 16, we show that first quarter 2010 was the second best quarter ever for our global market sales and trading businesses. Previous record was in the first quarter 2007 when we had a very different risk for finalizing, this makes this result even more impressive, this compared with the respected peaks in 2007 and subsequent we have cut our global markets balance sheet by almost 50%. We've cut our level three assets by 35% and we have cut our concept input volume 40%. So I think a very impressive result. Sales and trading revenue came in at €4.7 billion, after €255 in markdowns mainly related to monoline exposures. This compare to €4 billion revenue in the first quarter '09 after €1 billion of markdowns in certain other losses we had.

Our competitive position reflects the strong client franchise. Our results also do not include material legacy asset appreciation nor high levels of profit trading. Most impressive was the strong performance from our credit and equity businesses, which have gone through a substantial restructuring as we've reported to you in several occasions.

In sales and trading we brought a further development, which Anshu Jain has forecasted for 2010 on our Investor Day. In two weeks time, he will speak at Investment Conference and provide an update on the development in the first quarter.
In total this business is fully on track to deliver contribution to our 2011 profit target.

On page 17, we show that revenues in sales and trading debt were very strong and so we saw we expected normalization of revenues and our flow products such Money Markets, FX, and Rates. These businesses continue to generate very good revenue.

We have a high market share with clients and continue to invest to be here at the leading edge. In credit our recalibration has totally paid off. We have reoriented the platform to be more flow and client focused. We have been able to respond to investors to increase appetite for credit across investment grade, high yield and distressed product lines

In other areas we are also doing very well. The emerging markets franchise continues to, the emerging market franchise continues to generate excellent revenues across all regions but we especially also highlight here Latin America. In commodities we are yet to see all of the benefits of our investments in key hires and obviously we have seen a less favorable market conditions than in the first quarter of 2009.

Let me move on to page 18, in which we also show that in equities we had our best quarter since the fourth quarter of 2007, we have narrowed the gap to our peers, having gone through the significant recalibration of this business area. Our results were strong and positive in every product, also the contribution from our designated top trading platform remained at a very lower level this quarter.

In Equity Derivative, we've done some subdued client flow, but there has been demand for lightly structured products and we have changed our risk management approach here. First quarter 2009 as you remember was impacted by significant losses. In Equity Trading, cash equities market uncertainty impacted the volume.

In Prime Brokerage, we've maintained our market share and seen no balances, hedge fund clients are more active, also the environment is much more competitive than a year ago, but we are still doing well. We continue to commit very low resources to dedicated prop trading as shown at the Investor Day, this is not a driver of our business model and makes up less than 5% of our equities revenues.

One page 19, we show Origination and Advisory. We're very proud to announce that we rank number four globally for the first quarter 2010, up from number seven at year end 2009. In EMEA we have been number one, benefiting from a very strong performance in Germany. Some of our landmark deals in Advisory include Kraft Foods and Procter & Gamble as you know.
In origination Deutsche Bank was also involved in several landmark transactions in the U.S., which were obviously and are very significant for our franchise.

As communicated we are on the process of selling legacy assets in the first quarter 2010 this took place particularly in the Leverage Finance area but also in Commercial Real Estate. Overall in the first quarter we saw 645 million of CIB assets reclassified under IAS 39, in the first quarter at more or less they are carrying values.
We will continue to take any opportunities to reduce our exposure to legacy assets. And by the way, if we look into the second quarter we've seen a very strong momentum so far.

So let me move now on to the Global Transaction Banking business on page 20 you see the P&L, on page 21, you see the GTB reports in income before income of €100 million in the first quarter, and certainly weaker, as far as disappointing results in a difficult environment for our Transaction Banking business. Revenue remained subdued driven by obviously the low interest rate environment in both U.S. dollar and Euro rate. The interest in non-interest expenses by 82 million versus the first quarter of '09 reflects an impairment of intangible assets of 29 million. The career retirement acceleration effect of this business was impacted by 20 million as well as obviously higher regulatory expenses due to the deposit protection fund in Germany.

On the 1st of April, we must say we finally closed the acquisition of ABN AMRO's commercial banking business in the Netherlands. The operating P&L impact is anticipated to be roughly breakeven by 2010 due to one time integration costs, we look forward to a significant expansion obviously of our Dutch business with this acquisitions.
Let's go to PCAM on page 22. Let me highlight as we also did in our press release that after the acquisition of Sal. Oppenheim, we now manage invested assets of over €1 trillion.

On page 23, let me start now with asset management, as expected, we have seen no further significant impairment in the first quarter in asset management, first quarter has traditionally been a weaker quarter in the performance fee cycle as you know. However portfolio and fund management revenues further improved in an increasingly positive market environment. Profit of 30 million after again the deduction of 25 million for the aforementioned career retirement effect.

We have generated in this business. 4 billion of net new money mainly in our insurance assets. Our cost structure has further improved, head count have been adopted to the new environment with run rate cost savings down by approximately 25% year-on-year. So all the work we put to recalibrate and restructure asset management is starting to pay off and we have some additional measures underway to further improve our cost income ratio, for instance, the consolidation of our equity investment platform into Frankfurt.

On page 24, we see private, our Private Wealth Management business that adjusted for Sal. Oppenheim and compensation effect, the pre-tax profit was €24 million as we show you on the chart excluding Sal. Oppenheim revenues were up 15% year-on-year mainly due to higher transaction days, the revenue predominately due to increase in Asia Pacific, Northern Europe, Middle East and Africa and Germany.

We recorded very strong net money inflows of €5 billion mainly from Germany and Asia which fits our strategy to grow especially in these regions and again as the chart shows the PWM results was burdened by the consolidation of Sal. Oppenheim €59 million and the career retirement effect of – effects of 12 million.

Page 25, we show the P&L for the PBC business and at a glance if I move on to page 26, we saw PBC had a pre-tax profit of 189 million and that's the best result after the Lehman collapse if we adjust again for the non-operating items. So in the underlying a good performance. The first quarter of 2009 PBC profit had benefited from a release of credit losses – for credit losses of approximately 60 million on the year-on-year comparison in each, we take this one-time effect into account.

As forecasted we did record higher revenues from our investment business. Revenues from lending activity remain stable, while deposit revenues went up notably due to the improved margins. Credit provisions further declined which demonstrated again I think the quality of our PBC asset in generally – general and then also showed how our efforts, our improved collection efforts particularly for example in Spain has supported our good performance in this division.

Expenses benefited from efficiency measures as planned on the one hand but were more than offset by specific integration expenses and the affect from career retirement; an increased mandatory regulatory expenses, we were exposed to especially in Germany. All in all going forward we expect much healthier levels of underlying performance then in the pervious year.

Finally, to end my presentation, I just like to cover three key current issues. The first one is obviously the closing of the acquisition of Sal. Oppenheim in the first quarter; our complexity reduction programs and the quarterly performance in the context of our 2011 profit target.

As you know we closed the Sal. Oppenheim – on page 28 – we closed the Sal. Oppenheim transaction in the first quarter. The purchase price of 1 billion was paid in cash. That obviously excluded the BAS business, which was sold to Onz. We have now structured this business into four clusters. Cluster 1, comprises the wealth management in German – Germany and the asset management businesses in Germany and Luxemburg and that business for us represents the core franchise in Germany which is we will keep with distinct value proposition that's we will drive separate brand strategy.

Cluster 2, summarize Oppenheim's key international activities which will be combined or aligned with PWM's international activity where we are looking for a maximum of synergies and we will have a one brand approach. Cluster 3 includes all other Sal. Oppenheim businesses, some of this will be wound down or exited, but as you know the investment banking business, the private equity and the asset management and insurance business will be integrated into our corresponding DB activities and Cluster 4 is BHF where we're currently examining all our strategic options. So this highlights the approach.

And on page 29, beyond the impact on risk on capital that I already alluded to, this page summarizes the impact of Sal. Oppenheim Group on the division under division of P&L, so you have an idea of how much of the business got allocated to the different divisions.

PWM includes Clusters 1 to 3, however some of the asset management activities in Cluster 3 are allocated to asset management. The final allocation I want to say this very clear has a final allocation to this division is still under review and may change. This just represents our first and initial project.

On page 30, we show you our invested assets reporting for Sal. Oppenheim Group. We have now applied Deutsche Bank's invested assets concept in terms of the definition for the past and present numbers, to make it comparable with our numbers. Invested assets have grown mainly due to the consolidation of the insurance asset management business as well as due to market appreciation. You can see there was an insurance asset was not consolidated previously in the Sal. Oppenheim Group that led to this increase. A net new money outflows have been only marginally above 300 million in our corporate provision since the consolidation. So we see a very positive development.

With this acquisition on page 31 we give you some of its rationale, we obviously want to have undisputed leadership in Private Wealth Management in Germany. We want to have the complementary and added on client profile in the ultra-high network, net worth, individual client segment. We want to obviously have a second brand with a second wealth management propositions in the competition. We support obviously the acquisitions of Deutsche Bank to expansion in non-investment banking activities. And thirdly, we will represent a broader diversification of Deutsche Bank's earnings mix.

For 2010 and 2011 we expect some significant impact obviously now from integration, exit and synergy costs. This year we anticipate approximately 120 million in restructuring costs mainly severance costs, from 2012 onwards we expect then a positive contribution. All in all we see substantial upside potential from this acquired business.

On page 32 I want to give you a brief update on our complexity reduction program. As you know efficiency gains in complexity reduction is expected to result in about 1 billion of cost savings coming from a cost income ratio of 72% for the group by the end of 2009, and a very strong 66% by the end of the quarter. We target the cost income ratio of 65% by the end of 2011.

On page 33, I show you what we – how our process works. Since our Investor Day in December, we've set up a process in government structure and we've specifically committed cost savings accounting for about 550 million in efficiency gains with our different businesses. And this process obviously will continue on and all our initiatives will be centrally listed, quantified and further developed. The progress will be regularly tracked by our executives committee.

So on page 34, to sum up. Let's look at our first quarter results in the light of our 2011 profit target. Note that due to the typical seasonality in investment banking should not analyze our near record first quarter results. At first sight, the GAAP between the first quarter results in our classic banking business our profit target is quite remarkable.

However, if you look at the underlying performance we are not concerned as the operating performance of our business in the first quarter appears really in the reported number weaker than it actually was.

I remind you 298 million of career retirement charges are front-loaded and absorbed during the quarter, 120 million of U.K. bonus tax were recorded in PRBM digested a negative 558 million of Sal. Oppenheim, which was also driven by the integration so I think that we feel that we are very well on track. If we add up the range is about 3.2 to 3.3 billion of underlying business performance so even applying the usual seasonality affects of our business, we seem to be well on track on a Group basis to achieve our 2010 target.
So with that I conclude my presentation and I welcome any questions you may have.
Thank you. The first question is from Jernej Omahen, Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Hi, it's Jernej Omahen here from Goldman. I just have a couple of questions. The first one, I guess, is the obvious one on capital. You made a reference to market risk at some point in your presentation and I was just wondering whether the estimates for the increase in market risk at the end of the year still stand, so the 15 billion figure. And whether the timing of those – of that increase stands as well?

The second question is – also relates to a reference you made to the credit risk development during the quarter, I think that the suggestion was we shouldn't annualize the Q1 figure and I guess this is a relatively straight forward question, to what extent do you think that Q1 undershot your expectations for the run rate for the full year?

And then the next two questions, I guess more topical. The first one is the question on the disclosure you made at the back of your report from the subpoenas and requests for information. And you'll understand I feel slightly awkwardly positioned to ask this question, but can you maybe elaborate what those subpoenas relate to, I think you highlight the product so the RMBS and the CDOs is this the current investigation we are looking at in the U.S. or is that something different?

And then just the final question I guess, the Deutsche Postbank February 11 deadline is getting close and the discussion about potential actions of Deutsche Bank are getting louder and I was just wondering if you could update us on your thoughts here I guess given that we are relatively close to the timeline at this point? Thanks.

Thank you, Jernej. Let me go through your questions. The first on capital and expected increase to market risk by year end. As you know, the rules on capital are still under discussion. As you know, the European Parliament vote got delayed. We therefore expect now some delay in implementation so – overall we feel very comfortable with what we have always said that we believe that will continue to take some time and be less critical then many have assumed in various estimates. And I think what has happened since year end in this topic basically shows that we are right in terms of our views on this issue. So I think we will wait until final resolution gets, no change and that's I think the main message of – no change to our views, rather position and process developments that indicate that our forecast that we also gave at Investor Day is fine.

On the credit risk provisioning, yeah, we had a very good Q1 and no question and as I said you shouldn't project it out. We obviously based on the experience of 2009 did not give any specific guidance on capital position and I don't want to go into it but we would definitely think if it would trend high up in our current point of view than what an annualization of Q1 would suggest. Again there is still uncertainty in the environment, whilst we are very confident that our portfolios will perform well, IAS 39 assets might also bear a surprise, that's the reason why they are IAS 39 assets and therefore we might or could see volatility in this position as we experienced throughout the last year.

The subpoenas and legal situation, honestly there is no new information towards year end, we had that same, obviously based on what's going on in the external environment, disclosures of this nature generate some more attention. It is a standard and we had the same. It's not related to any current issues. It's not related to the issue you allude to. In fact only to clearly, as stated here, we have done our internal review we – of our transactions. We do not see that we have any similar situation than the one that is being discussed and therefore we don't have any concerns in that area.

Thank you also then for the Postbank question, because again I – will very loud and clearly say that our position on Postbank has not changed. The fact that the market has become a little bit more aware that there is some timeline considerations in the way we build the optionality structure in our structure. It's not new for us at Deutsche Bank and when we previously have indicated to the market that, number one, we have all the time of the world; number two, we see no pressure to move on quickly. In fact we even think that and see what the Postbank management is doing in terms of de-risking Postbank and continue to work an improved result this is very encouraging.

You know that we also have – continued to have very good reports on our contract with Postbank to get to synergies. So we are recovering all the synergies or getting to the synergies that you would normally expect by consummating a transaction sooner there will be no big difference, if we would be the owner of Postbank. So there is no incentive to move on quickly here and therefore again we can only say that we continue and our view is unchanged. There is no rush. There is no hurry to move on Postbank as the Postbank business itself and our synergies are going in the right direction.
Okay, thank you very much.
The next question is from Jon Peace, Nomura. Please go ahead, sir.
Yeah, hi. Good morning, everybody. Could I just ask three questions please?

Firstly on trading, obviously a very good result this quarter. But I wondered if you might be in a position to estimate what kinds of drag there might be from a liability tax. I know the German press have put a few figures around. And whether that might affect your 2010 goals?

The second question is on the core Tier-1. It's obviously a little low at the moment, but your core profitability will build back quite quickly. However, given regulatory developments, how should we think about dividends this year? Is it likely to be another year of fairly low pay out?

And final question is just on Greece. Would you be able to quantify your exposure to Greek government bonds? And would you expect any mark-to-market losses in the second quarter? Have you been able to hedge through CDS or some other mechanism? Thanks.

Jon, yeah, well, the big priority, we hear a lot about taxation around banks right now in the market, and we read in the newspaper. Though our main problem is we don't really have specific plans. We don't really know what the numbers are going to really look like. Therefore to make any focus at this point in time, it's just too early. We will have to wait what comes around.

Of course, again, like in every change, like the one we see in the rights capital exchange at the beginning, there is always big concerns that this may impact us significantly. I guess we will have to wait and see what finally comes before we can make a prediction how this will impact.

On dividends, it's very early in the year, as you know. In our financial statements, we always accrue versus our previous year basis, and obviously as you and I have to do the disclosure every year, to the dividend point, there will be decision of the AGM based on the proposals of our supervisory committee. We have no estimate at this point in time. We will have to see how the year develops.

And I think this is always a decision made quite late in the year depending on how our profit developed. But, as you know, we continue to be a committed to be dividend paying organization, and as we move on and as the environment allows us, obviously we will go back to increase this. But please accept this is too early to make any forecast.

To your Greek bond exposure, we were locked in the second quarter. We don't have much exposure to Greece directly – that's what we have always said. So we are not concerned. Obviously it always depends what the Greek situation then causes in the second magnitude of it. And obviously, we could not completely isolate ourself, if the situation in Greece gets somewhat worse, that there might be issues of a second nature or second category that might impact us. But our direct exposure, we're not concerned with.
Thank you.
The next question is from Philipp Zieschang, UBS. Please go ahead, sir.

Good morning. I'd like to come back to your risk-weighted asset guidance of the 50 billion net impact. So it's – then basically, the capital reduction you've published today, due to the securitization, is this an amount which wasn't in the guidance and which is now basically done and covered? Or would you expect further charges throughout the year? So could you just comment on the front loading part of the pain, which we've seen today on the Tier 1 ratio?

Second question would be with respect to the regulatory environment in the U.S., in particular with respect to the derivatives, what's currently being discussed in the Senate and has been now agreed by the Agricultural Committee in terms of moving the most of the OTC derivatives to exchanges – I was just wondering, is that covered in your chart on the Investor Day in December, in terms of the annualized 10% regulatory negative impact on sales and trading revenues in general? Or did you back then rather refer to the gearing impact, which should have been much more modest?
And then finally, could you just confirm that you haven't received any new wealth notice from the -
Okay.
Thank you.
Philipp, thank you. I am going to go in reverse order.
We have not received a wealth notice, to say it very clearly.

And your other question that referred to the application – or let me take your first question first. You have checked the application of the current rules. And we very clearly said this helps us in terms of our forecast, because it is already a rule application that we take that does lower our expectation for future impact, because that's exactly the type of impact we would expect to see in our securitization book. So it will reduce our further impacts. In that sense, it's front loaded, stretched to it.

Last thing – and you see what – said we have some taken pain here, but again, when we are – when the newer rules will come out, this will ease the difference – it will lower the difference that we will have to absorb at this point in time.

By the way, and I clearly want to say it here, this has not changed the profile, despite the fact that, based on the rule, we have to put some more tier capital on the books, the risk profile of the bank has not changed at all. This is – has something to do with the fact that according to this rule, any portfolio hedging we do to the securitization positions that are not one-to-one hedges basically do not count for the regulatory capital definition.

And therefore, whilst our VAR has not changed, and whilst our risk position and our balance sheet position to this securitization has not changed, we have to account for a higher capital charge, because portfolio-type hedging cannot be considered for this type of capital charge. So in that sense, this rule is very much in line with what we expect to come in terms of securitization capital charges.

Your derivatives regulation, as you know, we don't get tired to tell that all the time. Of course, when you do a forecast for profitability, you make a lot of assumptions. At that point our assumption was a different one in terms of what will happen with the derivatives portfolio and book, and therefore obviously we'll have to assess what this U.S. situation really means. But it is a change to what we had assumed the structure of the business will look like in our forecasted 10 billion target.
I'm sorry. If I may follow up on your last comment, but you've said in your statement that you are reiterating the CBS pre-tax profit guidance for -
